clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Post-Operative Sedation for Endovascular Thrombectomy
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Post-operative Sedation on Infarct Growth and Clinical Outcomes in Patients Receiving Endovascular Thrombectomy for Acute Ischemic Stroke

collaborator.agency: Shanghai Tongji Hospital, Tongji University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: Studies from our lab indicated that long-term sedation is protective in mice with midbrain infarct. To assess whether post-operative sedation has protective effects on the infarct size and clinical outcome in patients with ischemic stroke undergoing endovascular thrombectomy (EVT), a multi-center, randomized clinical trial will be carried out (POSET study). In POSET study, patients receiving EVT for acute ischemic stroke under general anesthesia will be randomly assigned to the control group (Con group) and the post-operative sedation group (POS group). Patients in the Con group will be recovered and extubated immediately after the surgery, whereas those in the POS group will be sedated with propofol and dexmedetomidine for 6h before extubation. The primary endpoint is infarct growth between CT perfusion (CTP) or MRI scans performed before EVT and 7 days after EVT. The hypothesis is that patients in the POS group will have less infarct growth.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from pre-operative infarct size at Day 7 after EVT surgery
primary_outcome.time_frame: pre-operative and at Day 7 after EVT surgery
primary_outcome.description: The infarct size will be measured with CTP or MRI before EVT and at Day 7 after EVT, and the difference in infarct size between these two time points will be calculated to reflect infarct growth

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from pre-operative NIHSS score at 24 hours after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-operative and at 24 hours after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The NIHSS classifies neurological deficit on a scale from 0 (no deficit) to 42 (most severe deficit).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from pre-operative NIHSS score at Day 7 after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.time_frame: pre-operative and at Day 7 after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The NIHSS classifies neurological deficit on a scale from 0 (no deficit) to 42 (most severe deficit).

secondary_outcome.measure: The infarct size at Day 7 after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The infarct size will be detected at Day 7 with MRI or CTP
Extubation delay is defined as more than 1h is needed from the time all sedative medication is stopped and recovery is started to successful extubation.
Extubation failure is defined as the need for ventilatory support after extubation using tracheal intubation or noninvasive ventilation within 24h after extubation.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 5 days
secondary_outcome.description: The time period from admission to ICU after surgery to move out from ICU to normal ward

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 14 days
secondary_outcome.description: The time period from admission to the hospital to discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: mRS score at Day 90 after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The Modified Rankin Scale (mRS) assesses disability in patients who have suffered a stroke and is compared over time to check for recovery and degree of continued disability. A score of 0 is no disability, 5 is disability requiring constant care for all needs; 6 is death.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mortality rate within 90 days after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.description: the mortality rate within 90 days after EVT surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of perioperative complication within 90 days after EVT surgery
secondary_outcome.description: The incidence of perioperative complication, including symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage, vascular injury, reobstruction, etc, within 90 days after EVT surgery

arm_group.description: Patients in the POS group will undergo EVT under general anesthesia. After the surgery is done, patients will keep being intubated and mechanically ventilated for 6h, during which period the patients will be sedated with propofol (TCI 1.0~3.0μg/ml) and Dexmedetomidine (0.2~0.7μg/kg/h) to maintain a BIS value of 50~70 and Ramsay sedation score of 5 ~ 6. The SBP will be controlled between 120 ~ 180mmHg with vasoactive drugs.

Patients in the Con group will undergo EVT under general anesthesia and will be routinely recovered and extubated immediately after the surgery is done. The SBP will be controlled between 120 ~ 180mmHg with vasoactive drugs for at least 7h after the surgery. In case the patient shows agitation after extubation, i.e., the Ramsay sedation score is 1, 0.02 ~ 0.1mg/kg of midazolam will be given. If the patient's Ramsay sedation score keeps being 1 and more than 0.2mg/kg of midazolam is given within 1 h, dexmedetomidine or propofol will be administered to calm the patient. Any patients in the Con group receiving dexmedetomidine or propofol within 24h after extubation will be excluded.

intervention.description: Patients with ischemic stroke will undergo endovascular thrombectomy (EVT) under general anesthesia. After the EVT surgery is done, patients in POS group will be sedated with propofol and dexmedetomidine for 6h before extubation.
Patients with ischemic stroke will undergo endovascular thrombectomy (EVT) under general anesthesia. Patients in Con group will be routinely recovered and extubated after the EVT surgery is done.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age: >=18 years
2. Preoperative National Institute of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) > 10
3. Pre-stroke modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score<3
4. Acute ischemic stroke in the anterior circulation, including internal carotid artery and middle cerebral artery
5. Indication for endovascular thrombectomy (EVT) under general anesthesia according to the 2018 AHA/ASA Guidelines for the management of acute ischemic Stroke
6. Informed consent by the patient him-/herself or his/her legal representative
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Additional intracerebral hemorrhage in the responsible vessel area within 6 weeks
2. Previous stent treatment in the responsible vessel
3. Coma on admission (Glasgow Coma Scale ≦8 points)
4. Allergic or contraindicated to heparin, aspirin, clopidogrel, rapamycin, lactate polymer, n-butyl methacrylate, stainless steel, anesthetics or contrast media
5. Hemoglobin level lower than 70g/L, platelet count less than 50×10^9/L, international standard ratio (INR) greater than 1.5 (irreversible), or with any irreversible bleeding factors
6. severe liver and kidney insufficient, ALT is higher than >3 times upper limit of normal value, AST is higher than >3 times upper limit of normal value, or creatinine is higher than >1.5 times upper limit of normal value
7. Pregnant or lactating women
8. A past history of mental illness
9. Having participated other clinical trials within 3 months
